newsitem.title: UK: UK confectionary sales up 5 pct - Cadbury.
newsitem.headline: UK confectionary sales up 5 pct - Cadbury.

text.p: British confectionary sales grew by five percent last year to a record 4.9 billion pounds, according to the 1996 Confectionary Market Review from Cadbury and its subsidiary Trebor Bassett.

Volume sales rose two percent to 833,000 tonnes, a growth of more than 12 percent over the last decade, to give an average 13 kilos each making Britain one of the highest confectionary consumers in the world, exceeded only by Denmark and Ireland.
Chocolate continues to make up most of the market with 70 percent of market sales at 3.4 billion pounds while sweets accounted for 30 percent at 1.5 billion, said the review.
Cadbury holds a 20 percent share of total confectionary and Trebor Bassett 10 percent.

This compares with other key players Nestle Rowntree with 20 percent and Mars with 18 percent. Cadbury makes chocolate confectionary while Trebor Bassett manufactures sweets -- each holds a market leading 30 percent share of their respective sector.

The Cadbury brothers launched Britain's first milk chocolate in 1897 in three penny and six penny packs. It was the forerunner of Cadbury's Dairy Milk which went on sale in 1905. Milk chocolate now accounts for almost 90 percent of chocolate eaten in Britain and there are now about 500 different confectionary brands on sale.
